title: 105_s1200
content: The Act may be cited as the "International Anti-Corruption Act of 1997" and includes limitations on foreign assistance. The President must submit a certification and report by March 1 each year to the appropriate committees regarding countries that received foreign assistance under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. The report should detail the economic progress of each country, including implementation of economic reform and elimination of corrupt trade practices. The certification submitted annually by the President assesses countries' economic progress, including reforms and anti-corruption efforts. It categorizes countries as conducive, not conducive, or hostile to US business. Assistance limitations apply to countries deemed hostile to US business. The President's annual certification assesses countries' economic progress and categorizes them as conducive, not conducive, or hostile to US business. Funds under the Foreign Assistance Act cannot be used for countries certified as hostile to US business, and the Secretary of the Treasury must vote against any loans to such countries in multilateral development banks. The limitations on countries certified as hostile to US business shall apply until the President certifies significant progress in economic indicators. Countries not conducive to US business are subject to a probationary period. Countries certified as not conducive to US business shall be on probation until the President certifies significant progress in economic indicators. This probationary period restricts funds for assistance under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 restricts funds for countries certified as not conducive to US business, with limitations on assistance until significant economic progress is certified by the President. The Secretary of the Treasury instructs against loans to such countries in multilateral development banks. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 restricts funds for countries not conducive to US business until certified by the President. Exceptions can be made for national security interests. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 restricts funds for countries not conducive to US business until certified by the President, with exceptions for national security interests. Assistance exceptions include urgent humanitarian needs, democratic political reform, private sector development, and free market economic system. The Secretary of Commerce will provide a toll-free number for reporting on the progress of countries receiving foreign assistance in implementing economic indicators. Information from the toll-free reporting will be included in the required report. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The term "appropriate committees" refers to specific committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate. The term "multilateral development bank" includes specific international financial institutions.
